The roughly 7-year life cycle of a video game console has been nearing an end. Both predecessor consoles, the Xbox One and the PlayStation 4, launched in 2013. The new consoles promise faster load times, souped up graphics and new games. Sonyâs console is also more expensive this time around; the PS4 launched for $400 in 2013. While you can still buy games on optical disks, itâs increasingly common for gamers to download them in digital form instead. The U.S., Japan, Mexico, Australia, New Zealand and South Korea will see the console on Nov. 12; everywhere else will get it a week later. In a presentation Wednesday, Sony previewed games including âSpider-Man: Miles Morales,â which will be available at launch, and a Harry Potter game, âHogwarts Legacy,â which will be out in 2021. Last week, Microsoft MSFT, +2.48% Â saidÂ its Xbox Series X will cost $500 and debut Nov. 10, just ahead of the holidays. A stripped down version, Xbox Series S, will cost $300 and be available at the same time. Pre-orders begin Sept. 22. It said on Wednesday a new version of its wire-free virtual reality headset, the Oculus Quest 2, will start shipping October 13, just in time for the holidays.
